content.description:
Dichlorophenolindophenol (<math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a chemical dye. When <math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is chemically reduced, it changes color from blue to clear. <math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be used as an electron acceptor in experiments that measure the rate of electron transport through the electron transport chain. A student performed an experiment to study the effects of a chemical, <math alttext="D C M U" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCMU</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, on photosynthesis.

The student prepared four tubes with a liquid buffer and chloroplasts that had been extracted from spinach leaves. The student then added <math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to three of the tubes and added <math alttext="D C M U" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCMU</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to one of them. Additionally, tube <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was wrapped in tin foil. The contents of each tube are shown in the table. The student then incubated each tube for <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>60</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes and measured the absorbance (<math alttext="A sub 600" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>600</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) of each solution at five-minute intervals. The absorbance readings of each solution are shown in Figure 1.

Tube <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>:
 Buffer and water

Tube <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>:
 <math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, buffer, and water

Tube <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>:
 <math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, buffer, and water (wrapped in foil)

Tube <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>:
 <math alttext="D C P I P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, buffer, and <math alttext="1.0 millimolar D C M U" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mM</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>DCMU</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Figure 1. Absorbance readings of four prepared tubes with various solutions over a <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>60</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute period.
content.question: Which of the following claims is best supported by the experimental results?

choices.label: Light is required for the electron transport chain to transfer electrons.
Water, not carbon dioxide, is the source of electrons used in the light-dependent reaction of photosynthesis.
Carbon dioxide is the source of carbon used by green plants to build carbohydrates.

<math alttext="D C P I P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DCPIP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> provides a significant source of electrons to the electron transport chain of the light reaction in the absence of light.

content.answer: Light is required for the electron transport chain to transfer electrons.

skill.text: 6.B: Support a claim with evidence from biological principles, concepts, processes, and data.
